title: 114_s385
content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" may be cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports by the Congressional Budget Office and Committees, completion of action on budget resolutions and reconciliation legislation, and consideration of appropriation bills in the House. The congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President's budget submission, reports by the Congressional Budget Office and Committees, completion of action on budget resolutions and reconciliation legislation, and consideration of appropriation bills in the House. Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by August 1, with the fiscal year beginning on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year when a new President's term begins, specific dates will override the usual deadlines in the congressional budget process. The congressional budget process includes deadlines for various actions such as the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in April, the Congressional Budget Office submitting a report by April 15, and Budget Committees reporting a concurrent resolution by May 15. Congress must complete action on the budget resolution by June 1, and certain appropriation bills may be considered in the House by July 1. The House must complete action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by July 20, with Congress completing action on these bills by August 1. The fiscal year begins on October 1, with Congress considering the defense appropriation bill and reconciliation legislation. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture and Commerce, Justice, Science. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts annual defense appropriation bills and biennial appropriation bills for various sectors. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts annual defense appropriation bills and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The term 'biennium' is defined as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Amendments are made to committee allocations in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and defense. Amendments are made to committee allocations in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium. Amendments are made to Title 31 of the United States Code. Amendments to Title 31 of the United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31 of the United States Code involve changing references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections related to functions, activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, tax expenditures, and future years. Amendments to Title 31 of the United States Code involve changing references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections related to functions, activities, allowances, uncontrolled expenditures, tax expenditures, and future years. This includes adjustments to prior year outlays and receipts for the two most recently completed fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31 of the United States Code involve changing references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections. This includes adjustments to prior year outlays and receipts for the two most recently completed fiscal years. Amendment to Title 31 of the United States Code changes references from "ensuing fiscal year" to "biennium to which such budget relates" for capital investment analysis. SEC. 5. TWO-YEAR APPROPRIATIONS; TITLE AND STYLE OF APPROPRIATIONS ACTS. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will state appropriations for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will specify appropriations for the fiscal year. The term "biennium" is defined in this section. The Control Act of 1974 and Acts described in subsection (a)(1) are subject to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. A technical and conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless no further appropriations are needed. Exceptions include defense, privileged measures, Executive Session matters, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. Amendment to Table of Contents: The Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section 316, which prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate, with exceptions for certain types of bills. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT requires joint oversight hearings by relevant committees on agency activities not funded under certain conditions. The hearings review agency mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD is also included. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will study the impact of changing the fiscal year to a 2-year period with a biennial budget process. A report on the findings will be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations starting from fiscal year 2017.
